title: plugins
description: Nuxt has a plugins system to use Vue plugins and more at the creation of your Vue application.

children.value: Nuxt automatically reads the files in the
directory and loads them at the creation of the Vue application.
All plugins inside are auto-registered, you don't need to add them to your
suffix in the file name to load a plugin only on the server or client side.
Only files at the top level of the directory (or index files within any subdirectories) will be auto-registered as plugins.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
-| plugins/
---| foo.ts      // scanned
---| bar/
-----| baz.ts    // not scanned
-----| foz.vue   // not scanned
-----| index.ts  // currently scanned but deprecated

children.value: To add plugins in subdirectories, you can use the

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: An array of nuxt app plugins.
Each plugin can be a string (which can be an absolute or relative path to a file). If it ends with

then it will be automatically loaded only in the appropriate context.
It can also be an object with
Plugins are also auto-registered from the

directory
and these plugins do not need to be listed in

unless you
need to customize their order. All plugins are deduplicated by their src path.
The only argument passed to a plugin is

children.value: It is also possible to define a plugin using an object syntax, for more advanced use cases. For example:

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: // this is the equivalent of a normal functional plugin
// You can directly register Nuxt app runtime hooks here
Throws an error if Nuxt instance is unavailable.
// Set this value to `false` if you don't want the plugin to run when rendering server-only or island components.

This enable the plugin for islands components.
Require
Watch a video from Alexander Lichter about the Object Syntax for Nuxt plugins.
If you are using the object-syntax, the properties are statically analyzed to produce a more optimized build. So you should not define them at runtime.

would defeat any future optimization Nuxt is able to do for your plugins.
Nuxt does statically pre-load any hook listeners when using object-syntax, allowing you to define hooks without needing to worry about order of plugin registration.
You can control the order in which plugins are registered by prefixing with 'alphabetical' numbering to the file names.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: will be able to access anything that was injected by
This is useful in situations where you have a plugin that depends on another plugin.
In case you're new to 'alphabetical' numbering, remember that filenames are sorted as strings, not as numeric values. For example,
. This is why the example prefixes single digit numbers with
By default, Nuxt loads plugins sequentially. You can define a plugin as
so Nuxt won't wait the end of the plugin's execution before loading the next plugin.

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: Execute plugin in parallel with other parallel plugins.
// the next plugin will be executed immediately
If a plugin needs to wait for another plugin before it runs, you can add the plugin's name to the

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: However, keep in mind there are some limitations and differences:
If a composable depends on another plugin registered later, it might not work.
Plugins are called in order sequentially and before everything else. You might use a composable that depends on another plugin which has not been called yet.
If a composable depends on the Vue.js lifecycle, it won't work.
Normally, Vue.js composables are bound to the current component instance while plugins are only bound to
If you would like to provide a helper on the
instance, return it from the plugin under a

children.value: You can then use the helper in your components:

Note that we highly recommend using
instead of providing helpers to avoid polluting the global namespace and keep your main bundle entry small.

This is due to how Vue works with refs that aren't top-level to the template. You can read more about it
If you return your helpers from the plugin, they will be typed automatically; you'll find them typed for the return of

to get the typed version. But in general, this should be avoided unless you are certain of the plugins' order.

children.value: Similarly, you can register a custom Vue directive in a plugin.

children.value: // you can provide SSR-specific props here
If you register a Vue directive, you
register it on both client and server side unless you are only using it when rendering one side. If the directive only makes sense from a client side, you can always move it to
and provide a 'stub' directive for the server in

html .light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html.light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
